header.topics: Scottish referendum, job interview, colleague, my daughter, present personal situation.

body.u: I got up had a wash had my breakfast erm and I went into work
erm we were putting the finishing touches to a to a erm
a thing a steel band that goes around the handrail on a wooden balcony that so that if anyone fell against the wooden balcony
and it broke it would you know its steel band would keep it all together
so we went and the steel band's got to be galvanised so
galvanised it's got to be galvanised
that means that it's dipped in a molten bath of zinc
it's cleaned with acid and then dipped in a molten bath of zinc
cos we often well sometimes use the word I was galvanised into action
doesn't really well anyway I was dipped in a bowl of zinc which
well there's galvanic action galvanic action is not believe it or not the same as galvanising someone or something
it's got a specific specific erm meaning in in metallurgy
mm okay so you got that done yeah?

mm got that done we dry fitted it you anything you make in a er that's got galvanised has got to be assembled you've got to be able to manufacture so that it can screw together into transportable and handleable pieces
rather than something that can be fabricated by welding it all together and erm the reason for that is that if you weld something that's been galvanised you destroy the galvanised coating

so that's what we did we did a dry run we fitted it we found out erm where there could be pitfalls we overcame any pitfalls and then we marked positions in it to drill counter some clearance holes for screws which would have provide holes for the screws to fix it to the handrail

yes and then we erm part of the balcony was rotten the wood and I went and bought some wood hardener which is like a mixture of resins in a in a solvent and you paint the wood with that the the resins sink deep into the wood er pardon me the solvent vaporises and then the wood hardens the wood becomes waterproof and hard and when then you can we use just a plastic filler on top of that resin for the resin filler to fill in bits of
wood to make it build it up
oh yeah you get your money off then? did you get your money off ?
I did paid er for that he's put it in my bank four hundred quid he pu did that the other day
I was thi I think I'll text him because he wants me to do more work down there
tile the bathroom which will be a day or two days' work down there fiddling around erm and so that's good and and er the opportunity for me to earn a thousand quid came in

so that will pay my national insurance contributions that I owe four hundred and thirty-one quid to hurrah and pay pay them er cos they were making noises the government has decided to change the ways in which er
which we are we pay our National Insurance contributions so I now have to well I don't have to I think pay it with your tax you pay it with the tax at the end of the year
do you? what if you're self-employed?
well that's what they're changing it to yes
which is fine by me it's great good idea
mm yes it is in a way erm good part about it is you you just have to muck about with it once
the the downside of course is that it's a large sum
well they never were that er they never pursued you very greatly when you didn't pay it
it wasn't something that they cared about much but erm what they did do erm er I know that I've got to pay one more year to qualify for my pension
how much is that a week?
hundred and thirty-five is it a week?
probably which is good to have you know
that's alright better than nothing and erm yeah it'll be brilliant to have that
well some people have to live on that don't they?
some people have to live on it
some people have to live on it I don't know how the hell they do I can't imagine how you one does
you have to be very careful
I would imagine you do bloody hell erm but er yeah
oh what happened in your day?
well first of all er I was thinking about phoning and then I tried on the on the Skype
immediately it said call failed I mean I tried call failed
so I thought what on earth is that about? so I tried er contacting you
and it went er and it was ringing so I thought okay it's well it's not my Skype that's er
so I used my phone to phone her and it said she was busy so I thought ah well that must be it but it

because er she the phone's being used and I mea so anyway erm she must have er when she'd finished talking she must have seen that I'd been trying to contact her because she ph she contacted me on Skype so

I managed to speak to and erm er you know it's the same thing every time I I feel so oh you know a mixture of guilt for not being there with her and being lonely and not seeing her but it I mean it's good that I do see her
so anyway er when that was finished then I decided to go and get those wellingtons or at least check them out
and I thought well before I do that I'll I'll go down to Vodafone because the contract I signed with them is two quid more than er it's two quid yeah it's two quid less than they've charged me for
well it's only two quid but you know two quid's two quid right? so I was going to go down to Vodafone to to find that out cos now I I I can check my account
and I can see how much I've used in minutes
and in er emails and although it's really very good how you how it's shown so anyway er that's what I'd planned to do and then do a bit of shopping
and I thought right so off I went and found the shop well actually I didn't see the shop straight away I went down the street which strangely enough is called street
a street named after you also and as I was walking down right opposite where this er er spiral shop is was a very small
nno it's a small office and it said er English lessons or something like that so I thought well
erm I'll pop in there anyway it doesn't look very big
just to see and there was this old Arab guy sitting at the desk
and I said salaam and he said salaam-Alaikum you know erm

yes and er I'm saying I'm an English teacher looking for work and then he sai oh really yes he said well you know you know started chatting chatting and erm so after about five minutes of us both standing there I said well shall we sit down? he said oh yes yes and so we sat down and very personable and we were chatting away and he was telling me about er his business
and I go I started to get the feeling that he must he must be a bit lonely cos he he started telling me about erm what are you looking for?
this is the new one I bought
oh right I've got it right on then
so he he's chatting the chatting
and er he's he's turned into er telling me about his life story
and how that he comes from Jordan and over there if you co and he comes from the desert and when you're you're in the desert you it's not like being born in a hospital there's no record of your birth
so honest he showed me his passport
and there's no date of birth on there
yeah er he's telling me about his family he's got five daughters erm they've all put have gone to college got masters one's
a solicitor and one works with him and all the rest of it

and it started it it star it he he was getting into it was like a life story you know and and then after I don't know about ten or fifteen minutes he said oh do you want a coffee or something? yeah thank you very much so I thought oh well I know it's a nice sunny day and I'm missing the sunshine but I've got nothing else to do so you know I'll chat with him and he was telling me about all what he used to do how he used to be a colonel in the army
and then was transferred to the air force
and at one stage had thirty thousand thirty-two thousand men ununder him
yeah and how er he's er you now got in contact with er princes er cos there are thousands of princes over there
and you know all the the all these important people that he knows and erm as as his life story ununfolded er
he was telling me about er over here he's got three masters degrees and he went to
for one of them and he actually well at some stage took out his phone and showed me a lecture or a talk rather not a lecture
there was a talk he was giving at Sussex University to a a group of people who have come er from all over the world or something
so I know it wasn't bullshit you know he he's a straight up guy
and while he's making the coffee I saw these framed certificates on the wall
er of how he's er an agent for all these different organisations
one of who is Kaplan you know you've heard me talk about them erm they're er a placement agency for lots of universities and things like that

and er he had three or four of these on the wall er so I sai and and he was telling me about his life and er ah he's you know done a lot of things er met a lot of people erm er some very important er and er he showed me a letter that he'd recently written cos somebody was wanting to find out about his company and
he showed me the letter I thought it was er to start with it was to check his English

and I I started and I said well the EngEnglish is perfect he he said yes but he said well what about the content? I said oh oh sorry I was reading it primarily for checking your and I thought that's what you wanted me to me to do but er he said I said yeah that's fine it's erm you know explained what about all hi about what his company does about how they find places at universities for students from abroad
which is pretty much what the the woman used to do on erm who was my next door neighbour who gave me the office you know?

and er and he said well yes he said er if I can he said er you know obviously it's a quiet time of the year but er if I can find you some work er you know I'll put you act as a middleman put your contacts said I don't want any money for it er I'll find you some work you know so I was I dunno I I told him a little bit about my background and we were chatting away there for over an hour
and nearly at the end of it my phone went and it was the DOS from that school that er I told you about wanted me to teach
and she said oh can you do my IOFS lesson on Monday morning?
do you need any books for that?

well yes but they've got one she said er in the school there where I can get photocopies from so I said right I'll I'll be er she said come come round about four o'clock I said okay so I had time to er go over the road buy my wellies and the belts and come back here and change and er went off there and saw her I saw her boss first of all who's also an IOFS examiner and he was telling me that he goes up to London to examine
because there's not much in you know they don't you know
and I thought well that's n I don't really wanna go up to London and he said and he said well erm it's only er an hour on the train
and it's er right behind station
so I said oh okay but it's er the they run it differently from china cos er here
it's er you get paid I think eight pound fifty for one interview and eight pound for a writing script
and what most of the examiners do they they do boo both speaking and writing but I never used to do writing
because you in China you have to be on BC premises that means you have to live in one of the four centres

like in Shanghai you you have to go actually go there so that's why he works there so what examiners do is that you only get about a a dozen interviews er and then they do mark er mark the writing scripts
and that's how they they make their money in a day

erm but it it wouldn't be worth it for me cos I'd onl I'm only certified er for erm for the speaking and it just wouldn't be worth it you know especially erm the after if you haven't tested for three months er then you have to you ddo six and they check to see if you're
marking accurately and then you can go for the full but in like in China you go for the weekend you stay in a five star hotel
and er you do thirty interviews for the weekend and er you know get about four hundred quid
for the erm for the weekend

but here it's it just doesn't seem like it's worth it you know? if if it's in Brighton it would be worth it but not not going up to London anyway he gave me a phone number of a woman to contact so I was chatting with the director of studies about what she wanted me to do and it was only er an hour and a half class on Monday morning and the way she described it is er they don't seem to be all that good as a school really cos er she said the type of work I can offer you at the moment is er is co on cover you know if if somebody er
and they she'll call me up
like half an hour's notice and say oh can you
come in straight away and do it of course you ca haven't got any time for preparation right?
you've got to wing it er which of course I could do but you fixed it?
well in there behind if you open it if you open it and withdraw the just open it click you little lever and open it
no open it that's it now if you see the little round button here
well that is hollow and in the back of there's a magnet
and the magnet is not a fixed it's loose in there it's w er and when you click that up to it pulls it off the magnet well
what happen is the magnet gets loose because it's loose it can jam up in there
and the magnet jammed up in there
oh you clever chap thank you very much

so erm anyway she at first first of all she started er saying oh er can you do reading exercises? and er so I said yeah alright and but in the end we decided that I was gonna do writing and er but the way
I thought you didn't do writing
yeah but I can teach it I can't

but anyway so we went through er what she wanted me to do and I I gave her my ideas and said right I'll need some photocopies of this and this she said yeah okay we'll get all that done for Monday morning er I said well coucould I come in on Sunday and they're closed at the weekends which for me is a very strange
concept because er in China everybody works seven days a week you know if you're the sort of language schools things and the weekends is the busiest time
anyway so Monday morning I've got my first lesson
oh it's not very much it's about fourteen and a half quid but it'll be even less than that
that's all you get for Monday morning?
well for an hour for hou I'll be doing an hour and a half so it's not very much
no of course not no you can walk there
I can walk there in fifteen minutes
oh that's just along the the the
so and it's a st first step you know
I'm I'm I'm fully behind you there
I'm not bemoaning the dosh I just think it's brilliant
you know you've got er you know you will soon you're brilliant at this
oh yeah I forgot I forgot to tell you when I was talking to this guy this Arab guy he's called
not and er he said you know what if I er could get you a a job er in er like a head of studies or something like that?
I said what would this be er in the Middle East? he said yes probably maybe a er saudi Arabia or Qatar

I said and I was sort of very thinking very quickly and I said well I've already erm seen adverts for jobs over there and I also one of my ex-colleagues er works in er Saudi Arabia and he lives on a compound and it sounds mm a bit isolated and all the rest of it and I said but but I said the reason I'm hesitating is that you know I've got a commitment in the summer to go and see my daughter er he said oh yes yeah of course of course er so so anyway in the end I just said er you know I'll send him my CV and
did he give you a an email address?
if he can get you something sorted out with er head of studies? blimey go for it that might be the thing that is fantastic buys you a little flat and er keeps your daughter in
it's erm I was telling him that the way I work as a teacher on one to ones
and I said whenever I get a new student I cos they always think or hope that they can make tremendous strides in a short time
you know and I tell them straight away like it is you know it's it takes a lot of study
to improve your standard of English you're not gonna do it it's not gonna be done quickly
er so that's the way I work I try and be honest and fair you know and tell them like it is from the start
erm so er I erm I said that and he said well yeah that's er er that's good and so er I hope that well I'll I'll send him my CV tonight
and er er in a week or two I'll pop in and just say hi and just do ccos he's obviously been an important man and is and is still
you know is if he's still giving talks at you know at university to
oh he's just telling welcoming everybody who come and er for the er talk and

well it was just welcoming people to the reason what they're I don't know what the reason was everybody congregated there had been summoned but he he'd been asked to give a talk so well a welcoming speech or something like that
and obviously I'm everything he told me I believed
you know he's obviously been er some different stages in his life a very important man with a lot of contacts
so I don't think it was bullshit so er anyway it's it's good to build up a relationship I'll just pop in and say hi you know so er all in all
it was right quite a positive day
and got my first teaching er for my first lesson

I would have thought though you could have commanded more money from than going in or on the chance of doing something for being called in for an emergency to cover is for fourteen quid an hour is seems to me
it is but beggars can't be choosers you know I I'm doing it
because I've got nothing else to do
except write off for jobs and it's gonna get me out of the house it's gonna get me teaching again
and iit's it's it's things like this one thing can lead to another you know
sure yeah no that's true that's true
I know it's it's pitiful money
it is but that's that's the way it is for just casual work but lolook at and how much trouble he's got finding any work I mean building labourer driver anything
is it bad? did he say it was bad then?
well he he told me that he'd he'd he's trying for all sorts of things writing off and he mentioned that er as far as driving jobs go he's he's er he's got convictions for dri you know and er he's
he he said well they'll just give me a chance and I'll even pay half the er increased cost of the insurance
yeah if they take him on and that kind of thing so I think he's pretty desperate to

I'm sure he is yeah I just yeah I have a deeply suspicious nature and and a paranoia about people anyway because I've been fucked and stuffed and ripped off and done over too many times sometimes for thousands of pounds so
I I I I've lived with people who just fucking lie they lie and lie and lie
well I mean I don't know
maybe he is but I s
so no no no no I but I I'm I I I tend to go along with what you think about it but

but yesterday the positive thing he was er said er you know hello to him and said oh how are you? he said oh I'm find yeah so it's like he said yeah I feel a lot better I said oh that's good and I went yes yes er and erm not that anything particular happened I think he's just doing what I'm trying to do dig himself out of this dark hole of depression you know and he seems like he's succeeding he's a lot perkier and er

I said er you know I said oh good you know well done erm I said you know some people look they look at a situation and they see a problem and other people they look at it and they see an opportunity so
and he said yeah absolutely so it seems like he's got his motivation there you know like he he seemed like he was down the other day
he seems a lot better in that er aspect or respect
well maybe it was partly the job getting him down
I don't know I I didn't ask him about you know did he leave or was he pushed
I thought well if he if he wants me to know he'll tell me you know so oh I'm starting to do it you know
you do it subconsciously or unconsciously don't you? you know cos you hear every
everybody saying it in the street or on TV
all levels of society right from
those people on benefits that we were listening to in the sh listening to only yesterday
right up to interviewers on national TV
you know what does it mean?
what do you prefer? do you prefer that or the American rising rising inflection?
it's er Australians speak like that as well

well I'd prefer if nobody says it because I was from a a teaching point of view if er somebody asks me well what does it mean? and how I would explain it it it really doesn't serve much purpose it's actually called classified as what's called a discourse marker and I thi I was trying to find another meaning you could substitute for it erm I suppose you could say it's short for er do you know what I mean? which is serves the same purpose er almost like a what we call a a tag question when tag questions are n
I think it's it's searching for reassurance that the person who's being told the information or the story is following it and understanding it and I think I believe they're they're they're asking for
so it may be the that erm and there's also a certain sense of something you know sharing about it
when they say you know you know it's rather like
or a beer it's you know you're you're joining in a story and
you're becoming you're you're sort of bonding
it's to encourage active listening isn't it? rather than passive listening where somebody's
active listening is when you're involved and you you do some uutter some kind of
response oh yes you know or things like this you know
unless the person talking is also addressing their their erm ego or or talking to themselves perhaps
I don't know maybe we do maybe we do talk to ourselves maybe it's said i in in parenthesis in in in a way it's er to ourselves how about that?

well I'm sure some academic has written some paper on it another thing I find very annoying in common parlance especially in young people is this overused word like like I was doing this like it's unreal like like and it it's well everything's like nothing is actually real it's it's er like so I said like erm
what instead of saying comparable to? you could compare it to that sort of
well again it it's it's it doesn't serve much
communicative purpose it's just a habit that people copy I suppose when we were young we had words that were everybody used in that generation like one springs to mind is cool every
all the ki cool oh that's cool
well that's what the kids say now
yes oh okay or far out far out man
no they don't say it any more
yeah so every generation's got its er
I say it to them because to my son and use as many obtuse words that I can remember from my youth because it makes him and his friends giggle
and he says people don't say that any more dad
it encourages it to m use it even more
well I suppose I'd better get back to my emails
great good that's good well done well it's this arm is getting much better now
unbelievable just I think I knew it would I knew it fucking would I I knew it wouldn't cos it's quite a thing I have I have quite a lot of you've seen those drinks of spinach that I have?
I mean that's but if you eat raw vegetables that's the best thing you can eat
it gives you so much energy
mm it's almost like your body's saying oh thank you at last
I've got some good things to nourish on
it is yeah that's right isn't it?
I'm going going to go and have a kip
okay I've put some clothes that were dry from over there on your bed
oh thanks thank you thank you indeed yeah
